content.description: Strenuously pull through the roof and follow the crack until you can easily traverse left to the top anchors of Sexcellent.
content.protection: Standard Rack. An extra #3 and/or #4 might be handy for some.
content.location: Climb the obvious roof/crack from the top anchors on Ryobi. Rap down from Sexcellent with one rope in two rappels.

content.description: A fun and interesting line bolted by someone with a keen eye! 6 bolts diagonal up and right following the diagonal crack lines and ramps. Smartly bolted, this route offers great rock and a huge variety of climbing styles in 45 feet. Two crux sections- the first is from bolts 3 to 5- sneak through with in-obvious balancey moves that seem like trickery. The second is around bolt 5 and is a little more thuggish. In cool conditions i'm sure neither of these cruxes would be harder than v4, but in the summer heat 12c is probably correct. Listed as 12b/c in the Bingham guide.
content.location: Slightly down hill and to the left of the approach ramp/gully used for Shock and Awe (10a) and Claim Jumper (11c). On the Squench rib.

content.description: This fun diverse route starts on patina edges.  The crux hits low with in a maze of small patina holds facing different directions.  Continue on with tricky pull-down edging leading to a steep jug finish.
content.protection: Bolts.  Bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: South side of the West Buttress of Castle Rock

climbs.name: Sexcellent
climbs.fa: Mike Engle, Chris Barnes, and Vernon Phinney

content.description: P1 one is a very fun outing of ever steepening patina until you pull the 5.10 crux at the final bulge.  P2: step up right to the edge of the arete and make a desperate but well protected 5.11 move to gain a line of patina to the anchors.  P3: A short but nice 5.7 pitch takes you to the top of the formation. One 60 meter rope will get you down in 3 rappels.
content.protection: About 12 quickdraws on 1st Pitch, about 9 on the 2nd, and 4 on the 3rd.  Chain Anchors at the top of each pitch.
content.location: On the center of Castle West Buttress - South right of "Olypus Wrecks" and left of "Tiers of Joy" in Dave Bingam's Castle Rocks guidebook. From a deep gully on the ground,stem out quickly onto the face and generally follow a patina line staying just left of right trending crack to an arete major feature. One 60 meter rope will get you down in 3 rappels.

climbs.name: Scorpio Rising
climbs.fa: Brian Cabe and Patty Black April 2003

content.description: A fun steep start, then a short break, leads to a slight over hang on big holds.  Up the face to a corner, around just to the left, then up to the anchor.
content.protection: 6 lead bolts to a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
Located just to the right of Poking Holes in the Firmament and straight across from Twinkie and Ho Ho.

Rappel route.

climbs.name: Ryobi
climbs.fa: Chris Barnes, Vern Phinney, Mike Engle

content.description: Friction up and over an early overlap, continue up the slab towards the cedar tree and pull across a flake edge to a steeper patina line to the anchors under an overhanging dihedral.  Above this is the 2nd pitch of Tiers of Joy.  It was discovered after the fact that Ryobi loosely followed some sections of the somewhat runout original Tiers of Joy first pitch. Brad Shilling (FA of Tiers of Joy and climbing ranger at the time) was notified immediately of the potential retrobolting and he gave his blessing to the new line.  It can now be used as an approach pitch to the excellent 2nd pitch of Tiers of Joy (5.10 full on trad).
content.protection: 10 quickdraws. One 60 meter rope for rapellling or lowering to the ground.
content.location: Fun slab left of "Poking Holes in the Firmament". Climbs a well bolted line right of an obvious small tree about 1/3 the way up.

climbs.name: Poking Holes in the Firmament
climbs.fa: Patty Black and Brian Cabe April 2003

content.description: One kinda crux move is stepping off the ground onto the climb.  Very mellow but fun climb recommended for beginners, good bolts, big holds, cool featured rock!
content.protection: 6 Bolts will get you to the fixed anchors on the ledge above and your rappel.
content.location: Directly ACROSS the gully from the mail wall facing east.  This route is 60 feet below or left of Scorpio which is directly across the gully from "Ho-Ho".  Climb starts right off the trail!

content.description: The crux is certainly the thin tricky layback at the beginning of the climb but its a toprope so no excuses (from "Poking Holes" anchors).  Very fun and challanging route not to be missed while waiting for the long routes across the gully.
content.protection: No Pro; toprope from the 5.6 route just 5 feet to the right of this route.
content.location: Route is about 5 feet left of "Poking Holes" route and is the thin crack at the bottom angling up and right and begins right off the Hostess Gully trail.

content.description:
Another of Duane Ackerman's recent additions to the single-pitch side of the Hostess Gully. This route is very well-protected and would make for an excellent first lead. With 7 bolts in 60 feet on huge holds, this route is a fine choice for kids and anyone looking for a mellow romp on steeper terrain than much of the standard Castle Rocks slab.

This route leads to the same chain anchors used by Genevive.
content.protection: 7 closely-spaced bolts to chain anchors (shared with Genevive).
content.location: Just a few feet right of Genevive. Roughly twenty-five meters up the hill from the huge boulder at the base of Poking Holes in the Firmament.

content.description: Good beginner route. Steep start crux is bolt-protected. Three moves of 5.7 or 5.8 climbing, but then it eases into enjoyable 5.5 climbing to chain anchors. Big holds from start to finish.
content.protection: Three bolts in 60 feet, but you can supplement those with small and medium gear.
content.location: Twenty meters up the hill from the ever-popular Poking Holes in the Firmament. Start on the flat area below the boulder, or stand on the boulder, clip the first bolt, and start from there.

content.description: A great climb to do if there is a wait for Shock and Awe. This short climb starts with 5.8-ish friction up a slab. You can pro the slab with a small TCU. Once at the top of the slab, you can reach up and clip the first bolt. Power-move your way up over the roof and then finesse your way up a friction face to a set of chain anchors.
content.protection: 7 Bolts plus gear for chain anchors.
content.location: This route is on the boulder just before you enter the gulley up to the start of Shock and Awe.

content.description: Interesting and enjoyable moves through most of the route.  Difficult to tell exactly where the intended route goes through the roof (crux).  The difficulty of the crux eases off to about 10c/d depending on where you attack the roof.
content.location: Start on the face to the right of Shock and Awe.  Uses the top anchors of Shock and Awe (West Buttress/Spur of Castle Rock).

content.description: Climb a mungy, low-angle left leaning crack to access the corner.  The actual corner climbs well with lots of face holds and fun stemming. The crux is a short section requiring a layback.  Traverses right at the top to the anchor.
content.protection: Single set of cams up to BD #3.  2-bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is the obvious arching corner left of

Poking Holes in the Firmament

.  It shares the same anchors.

content.description:
The striking and enjoyable arête just left of the classic

Shock and Awe

is, in my opinion, just as classic due to the position and crux moves. But then again, I'm a huge fan of arêtes and airy, exposed climbing. If you're like me in that respect, you're sure to enjoy this fine line.

From the same big ledge belay for

Shock and Awe

, head slightly down and left to get to the start of the arête. Clip a couple of bolts from good holds to a small roof/bulge. Figure out how best to pull this bulge and then clamber up the tiny dihedral past a few more bolts to a good ledge below the obvious arête crux above.

Slap and heel hook the arête and pull through a few committing moves to the great clip hold above the crux allowing you to get established in the huge hueco just right of the arête. Take a moment to enjoy the airy and exposed position before making the final moves to the anchor.

According to Bingham's book, the 5.11c crux can be avoided by going far right of the huge hueco near the crux. I didn't try this and think that would be quite a pendulum swing if you didn't make it. The crux moves are cool and well protected so you might as well keep it real on the arête.

The 11c moves require height and reach.  Move right along the ledge/slab to the right side of the hueco.  Climb the jugs and chicken heads on the right side. Make a long reach left to clip the bolt in the hueco. Either step into the hueco and stem upward or continue to hug the jugs on the right to gain the final bolt and anchors.
content.protection: 10 bolts to a two-bolt anchor. Bingham's book description suggests medium cams for the cracks in the tiny dihedral about half way but I didn't feel the gear necessary. Note that a 70m rope won't get you all the way back down to terra firma from the big ledge below the start of these routes. With a 70m rope you can lower your partner all the way down (just barely) but the last person will have to downclimb in the corner below this route.  Carry two or three cams from 1-3 for the crack between the bolts.
content.location:
Just left of

Shock and Awe

is this obvious bolted arête.

content.description: This is the natural line just to the left of Olympus Wrecks.  Start about 20 ft to the left in a very thin tips/finger crack.  The meat of this climb is fairly short but hard right from the start.  Take a right leaning very thin tips crack up and into the crux of Olympus.  The two routes meet for 10 feet, using the highest bolt of Olympus when gear disappears.  Once you have reached the good stance take the left crack/corner to the roof and out left to the anchors of Ad-vance to Idaho.
content.protection: small stoppers and micro cams.  the upper crack will take a few fingers to thin hands.  1 draw

content.description: This is the last route on the left side as you move up the gully. Although short, it is fun and worth doing. The holds are all positive. You will want at least 2 pieces (gear to 2 inches) to supplement the bolts and prevent ground fall.
content.protection: 3 bolts, at least 2 pieces of gear (size up to 2 inches).
content.location:
The last route on the left as you move up the gully. The Bingham guide seems to be a little bit off in the description of the starts for Genevive, Just Right and Accidental Spice. You

do not

want to get this mixed up with Just Right.
